thread.title: Suburbs or the city: Where to raise children in Melbourne as birth rates boom
thread.title_full: Suburbs or the city: Where to raise children in Melbourne as birth rates boom

author: Kirsten Robb
title: Suburbs or the city: Where to raise children in Melbourne as birth rates boom
text:
print Victoria Davis says it is relaxing to watch the rhythmic blinking of car lights in a West Gate Bridge traffic jam from her Docklands high rise apartment, where she is raising two children with her husband. 
Often, her friend Maria Torres Richter is in that gridlock, heading back to her four-bedroom house in Werribee. When she gets home, she and her husband Daniel relax by chasing their twin boys around the backyard. 
The friends represent how young families make divergent choices on how and where to raise children in Melbourne. While the majority take the traditional route to affordable fringe suburbs, many are rethinking inner-city living. And both have their pros and cons: including an increasing strain on schools and childcare in those areas. 
Daniel Richter and Maria Torres Richter value having a big backyard for their twin 2-year-old boys Gabriel and Marcel. Photo: Pat Scala 
The City of Wyndham — a council that includes house and land package heartlands Point Cook and Truganina — boasts the highest birthrate in metropolitan Melbourne. The Wyndham baby boom saw Werribee Mercy Hospital deliver 3748 babies last year and already another 331 in January. The hospital increased monthly maternity bookings and employed extra staff to keep up. 
Birth rates are similarly high in Cardinia, Casey, Hume, Mitchell and Melton shires: “Those outer areas are generally where people go to buy a house, settle down and have kids,” demographer Glenn Capuano of .id said. “But Wyndham is probably the most affordable fringe housing in Melbourne at the moment.” 
Although the City of Melbourne has a low birthrate (a formulation based on the population’s fertility), it is witnessing its own mini boom, with the crude number of babies on the rise because simply more people are living there. The council is now one of the fastest growing. More people means more births. 
Melbourne’s population continues to explode from a combination of births as well as huge migration numbers. Photo: Eddie Jim 
Both councils say they recognise the challenges more bubs places on local schools and childcare, and want the state government to help them keep up with demand. 
Ms Davis is about to add another baby to Docklands, but says she hasn’t encountered any problems with schools or childcare in the area. But she says she still gets a reaction when people found out she is raising kids in a three-bedroom apartment. 
“But those people are usually from the suburbs and haven’t thought about it themselves,” she said. “I grew up in the suburbs and my parents were never happy there, suburban life is not for everyone.” 
Your view of Melbourne as a value for money proposition will depend on where you live. Photo: Paul Rovere 
With a 20 second commute to work — she and husband Demian Gibbins own The Espressonist cafe at the bottom of their apartment tower — Ms Davis says they save on petrol, parking and time. “My husband wouldn’t be able to see the kids if he was commuting because he’d get home and they’d be asleep.” 
For Ms Torres Richter, the priority was living close to her mum in Point Cook, who helps with childcare while she’s running her business, Torres Jewel Co. Affordability and a good chance for capital growth were the other reasons she and her husband Daniel Richter, a real estate agent with Brian Mark, wanted to raise their kids in Werribee. 
“Before I had kids, my vision was that I would be closer to the city, but once I had babies, I just see now how important it is to for them to be outside in the grass,” she said. “The boys are toddlers so they’re always climbing things, I’m happy for them to have that traditional upbringing.” 
Werribee Mercy Hospital delivered 3748 babies last year. Photo: Michael Copp 
The City of Melbourne plans to create 215 new childcare places and a spokeswoman said the council was also seeking state government action to ensure adequate provision for schools. 
“Our increasing, changing population is a big issue for the City of Melbourne, and we are working to make sure we can continue to help families live, work and play in our growing city,” she said. 
In Wyndham, the council wants state and federal governments to ensure planning for growth areas is high on their agenda. 
“They have not caught up in some areas in the planning for and delivery of social and physical infrastructure,” mayor Henry Barlow said. “Melbourne is considered the most liveable city because of, among other things, the accessibility of vital services. If you apply that standard to a major growth area it would create a challenge for Melbourne retaining that reputation.” This week's must see listings
